Description: Disallows slash-delimited date literals; they depend on language/locale and can silently change meaning - prefer ISO 8601.
Disallows @@IDENTITY; it can return values from triggers - prefer SCOPE_IDENTITY() or OUTPUT.
Detects EXEC with dynamic SQL (EXEC(...) pattern) which can be vulnerable to SQL injection
Warns when tables are created as heaps (no clustered index); heaps can lead to unpredictable performance and maintenance costs.
Detects CAST or CONVERT applied to columns in predicates which can cause implicit type conversions and prevent index usage
Warns on datetime CONVERT style numbers (magic numbers); encourages clearer, safer formatting patterns.
Avoid using MERGE statement due to known bugs (see KB 3180087, KB 4519788)
Avoid using NOLOCK hint or READ UNCOMMITTED isolation level
Detects NULL comparisons using = or <> instead of IS NULL/IS NOT NULL, which always evaluate to UNKNOWN.
Avoid SELECT * in queries.
Disallows TOP in UPDATE/DELETE; it is frequently non-deterministic and easy to misuse without a carefully designed ordering strategy.
Detects legacy outer join syntax (*=, =*) which is deprecated and produces incorrect results.
Detects query hints and table hints that bypass the optimizer, causing long-term maintenance issues.
Detects CATCH blocks that suppress errors without proper logging or rethrowing, creating silent failures.
Require BEGIN/END blocks in conditional statements for clarity and maintainability
Discourage cross-database transactions to avoid distributed transaction issues
Detects destructive DDL operations (DROP, TRUNCATE, ALTER TABLE DROP) that can cause irreversible data loss.
Recommend specifying DATA_COMPRESSION option in CREATE TABLE for storage optimization
Prohibit cursor usage; prefer set-based operations for better performance
Flags SELECT DISTINCT usage which often masks JOIN bugs or missing GROUP BY, and has performance implications.
Warns on SELECT ... INTO; it implicitly creates schema and can produce fragile, environment-dependent results.
Detects UPDATE/DELETE statements without WHERE clause to prevent unintended mass data modifications.
Avoid consecutive empty lines (more than one blank line in a row).
Avoid consecutive GO batch separators.
Warns when a Transact-SQL keyword is used as a table/column identifier without escaping, and offers an autofix to bracket it.
Forbids TOP 100 PERCENT ORDER BY; it is redundant and often ignored by the optimizer.
Prohibit full-text search predicates; use alternative search strategies for better performance
Prohibit INFORMATION_SCHEMA views; use sys catalog views for better performance
Warns when INSERT target column names do not match SELECT output column names in INSERT ... SELECT statements.
Detects comma-separated table lists in FROM clause (implicit joins) and suggests using explicit JOIN syntax for better readability
Prohibit linked server queries (4-part identifiers); use alternative data access patterns
Prohibit named constraints in temp tables to avoid naming conflicts
Avoid nested block comments (/* /* */ */).
Detects SELECT TOP ... INTO without ORDER BY, which creates permanent tables with non-deterministic data.
Detects functions applied to columns in WHERE, JOIN ON, or HAVING predicates which prevents index usage (non-sargable predicates)
Prohibit OBJECTPROPERTY function; use OBJECTPROPERTYEX or sys catalog views instead
Disallows invalid ORDER BY in subqueries unless paired with TOP, OFFSET, FOR XML, or FOR JSON (SQL Server error Msg 1033).
Detects nested ISNULL and recommends COALESCE; reduces nesting and aligns with standard SQL behavior.
Recommends CONCAT() when + concatenation uses ISNULL/COALESCE; avoids subtle NULL propagation (SQL Server 2012+).
Stricter variant that also detects CAST/CONVERT in concatenations; enable instead of prefer-concat-over-plus for comprehensive coverage (SQL Server 2012+).
Recommends CONCAT_WS() when concatenation repeats the same separator literal; improves readability and reduces duplication (SQL Server 2017+).
Encourages built-in JSON features (OPENJSON, JSON_VALUE, FOR JSON, etc.) over manual string parsing/building (SQL Server 2016+).
Recommends STRING_AGG() over STUFF(... FOR XML PATH('') ...); simpler and typically faster/safer (SQL Server 2017+).
Recommends TRIM(x) instead of LTRIM(RTRIM(x)); clearer and less error-prone (SQL Server 2017+).
Recommends TRY_CONVERT/TRY_CAST over CASE + ISNUMERIC/ISDATE; fewer false positives and clearer intent.
Prohibit PRINT statements; use THROW or RAISERROR WITH NOWAIT for error messages and debugging
Requires qualifying columns in SELECT lists when multiple tables are referenced; prevents subtle 'wrong table' mistakes when column names overlap.
Column aliases should use the AS keyword
Table aliases should use the AS keyword
Enforces BEGIN/END for IF/ELSE blocks, while allowing a single control-flow statement (e.g., RETURN) without a block.
Enforces BEGIN/END for every WHILE body to avoid accidental single-statement loops when code is edited.
INSERT SELECT statements must explicitly specify the column list to avoid errors when table schema changes
INSERT VALUES statements must explicitly specify the column list to avoid errors when table schema changes
Disallows ambiguous JOIN shorthand; makes JOIN semantics explicit and consistent across a codebase.
Ensures table definition files include an MS_Description extended property so schema intent is captured alongside DDL.
Detects mixed AND/OR operators at same precedence level without explicit parentheses to prevent precedence confusion.
Requires PRIMARY KEY or UNIQUE constraints for user tables; helps enforce correctness and supports indexing/relational integrity.
Requires column qualification in WHERE / JOIN / ORDER BY when multiple tables are referenced; stricter than qualified-select-columns.
Requires TRY/CATCH around explicit transactions to ensure errors trigger rollback and cleanup consistently.
Requires SET XACT_ABORT ON with explicit transactions to ensure runtime errors reliably abort and roll back work.
Detects potential scope violations where aliases from outer queries are referenced in inner queries without clear correlation intent.
Ensures variable references match the exact casing used in their declarations for consistency.
Detects CTE name conflicts with other CTEs or table aliases in the same scope.
Requires explicit length specification for variable-length data types (VARCHAR, NVARCHAR, CHAR, NCHAR, VARBINARY, BINARY).
Detects duplicate table aliases in the same scope, which causes ambiguous references.
Detects column count mismatches between the target column list and the source in INSERT statements.
Detects JOIN conditions that are always true or likely incorrect, such as 'ON 1=1' or self-comparisons.
Detects LEFT JOIN operations where the WHERE clause filters the right-side table, effectively making it an INNER JOIN.
Requires column references in multi-table queries (with JOINs) to be qualified with table aliases for clarity.
Detects unreachable statements after a RETURN statement in stored procedures or functions.
Requires all table references to include schema qualification (e.g., dbo.Users) for clarity and to avoid ambiguity.
Recommends using SELECT for variable assignment instead of SET for better performance and consistency.
Detects references to undefined table aliases in column qualifiers.
Detects Unicode characters in string literals assigned to non-Unicode (VARCHAR/CHAR) variables, which may cause data loss.
SQL statements should be terminated with a semicolon
Files should start with SET ANSI_NULLS ON within the first 10 statements.
Files should start with SET NOCOUNT ON within the first 10 statements.
Files should start with SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER ON within the first 10 statements.
Files should start with SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL within the first 10 statements.
Detects TOP clause without ORDER BY, which produces non-deterministic results.
Detects BEGIN TRANSACTION statements without corresponding COMMIT or ROLLBACK in the same batch.
Detects UPPER or LOWER functions applied to columns in WHERE, JOIN ON, or HAVING predicates which prevents index usage
Detects local datetime functions (GETDATE, SYSDATETIME, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP, SYSDATETIMEOFFSET) and suggests UTC alternatives for consistency across time zones
